item.title: Phishing
item.description: An attempt to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information through fraudulent emails, websites, or messages.

item.title: Phishing Email
item.description: An email sent by attackers that appears legitimate but aims to trick recipients into revealing sensitive information or performing actions.

item.title: Social Engineering Toolkit (SET)
item.description: A framework for simulating social engineering attacks, helping organizations test their security awareness.

item.title: Advanced Persistent Threat (APT)
item.description: A prolonged and targeted cyber attack in which attackers gain and maintain unauthorized access to a network.

item.title: Cyber Espionage
item.description: The use of cyber techniques to steal sensitive information from governments, organizations, or individuals.

item.title: Zero-Knowledge Proof
item.description: A cryptographic method that allows a party to prove knowledge of a secret without revealing the secret itself.

item.title: Security Operations Center (SOC)
item.description: A centralized unit that monitors, detects, and responds to cybersecurity incidents and threats in real-time.

item.title: Data Loss Prevention (DLP)
item.description: A strategy and set of tools to prevent the unauthorized loss or leakage of sensitive data.

item.title: Endpoint Security
item.description: The protection of devices like laptops, desktops, and smartphones from various security threats.

item.title: Security Token
item.description: A physical or digital device used to authenticate users or provide one-time passwords for secure access.

item.title: Network Security
item.description: The protection of network infrastructure and data from unauthorized access or attacks.

item.title: Payload
item.description: The part of a malware or exploit that performs malicious actions on a victim's system.

item.title: Cryptography
item.description: The practice of secure communication by converting plaintext into ciphertext and vice versa.

item.title: Social Engineering Attack Vectors
item.description: Different methods and techniques used in social engineering attacks to manipulate victims.

item.title: Threat Hunting
item.description: Proactively searching for and identifying cyber threats that have evaded traditional security measures.

item.title: Incident Response
item.description: The process of managing and mitigating the impact of a cybersecurity incident or breach.

item.title: Privilege Escalation
item.description: The act of gaining higher levels of access or permissions in a system or network than originally granted.

item.title: Security Assessment
item.description: A systematic evaluation of an organization's security measures to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses.

item.title: Data Encryption Standard (DES)
item.description: An early symmetric key encryption algorithm used to secure electronic data.

item.title: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)
item.description: A widely used symmetric key encryption algorithm known for its security and efficiency.

item.title: Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
item.description: A system for managing digital certificates and public-private key pairs used in asymmetric encryption.

item.title: Certificate Authority (CA)
item.description: An entity responsible for issuing and managing digital certificates used in PKI.

item.title: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
item.description: An older cryptographic protocol that provides secure communication over a computer network.

item.title: Transport Layer Security (TLS)
item.description: A more secure successor to SSL, providing encryption and authentication for secure communication.

item.title: Key Exchange
item.description: The process of securely sharing encryption keys between parties to establish a secure communication channel.

item.title: Malvertising
item.description: Malicious online advertisements that deliver malware or lead to malicious websites.

item.title: Eavesdropping
item.description: Unauthorized interception and monitoring of private communications, often done surreptitiously.

item.title: Identity Theft
item.description: The fraudulent acquisition and use of an individual's personal information to impersonate them for malicious purposes.

item.title: Zero-Day Vulnerability
item.description: A software vulnerability that is not yet known to the vendor or the public, making it highly valuable to attackers.

item.title: Security Patch
item.description: An update released by software vendors to fix security vulnerabilities in their products.

item.title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
item.description: A type of web vulnerability where attackers inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users.

item.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
item.description: An attack that tricks a user into unknowingly submitting a malicious request on a trusted website.

item.title: Phishing Email
item.description: An email sent by attackers that appears legitimate but aims to trick recipients into revealing sensitive information or performing actions.
